A somewhat large subsection of gamers chew gum while playing.  The reason??? Adderall, cocaine, meth, or ecstasy. Stimulant drugs make video games more enjoyable and they enhance players‚Äô reaction times. One side effect of stimulant abuse is ‚Äúgurning‚Äù. In this context that term refers to involuntary stimulation of the facial muscles that often results in heavy teeth grinding or clamping which can cause damage to the jaw/teeth and soreness once the affects wear off. Gum alleviates the severity of this by giving you something to focus on and providing some cushion for the jaw/teeth.

It's sad. I loved 5 Gum, even tho it was way overpriced for our country and my shallow pockets at the time. It's funny when you think about it - coincidentally 2015 was basically the time I stopped buying 5 Gum. They changed for the worse. The main question is: why are marketing directors so retarded? Why are they convinced that they could spend 5-10-years to create a following of young boys by marketing their product to them and then suddenly shift their focus towards teen girls and expect to keep their initial followers, while gaining new ones in the face of the new target audience? It doesn't work this way - never did, never will. It's the same with games, movies and etc. If your audience is predominantly 14-25-years old males, then you market your products to them specifically and enjoy the money you get. Suddenly shifting your focus towards a new audience would only make you lose our current one. And what happens if you are unsuccessful at attracting a new audience with this bold (stupid) move? Well, you lose everything. It's like going from sitting on one chair and then attempting to sit on two chairs at the same time. But here's the kicker - sometimes when you try sitting on two chairs you happen to fall down on your arse. Oh well!

It might seem silly, but the 5 packaging really was a great thing. Before 5, you could still buy packs of 15 stick of gum. The issue is that they came stacked on one top of the other, then wrapped with a little tear tab at the top that removed the whole top. As you removed sticks, this would create more space and they would all be loose and fall out into your bag/purse by the third stick. Very inconvenient. The re-closeable packaging from 5 got rid of this. Although wider, it was flatter- more pocket friendly than the 15-stick stack.
Say what you want. It tasted amazing

I think most trend (regarding product consumption) are meant to stay in the past.  Today the industry who succeeded to domesticate trend is fashion. They do as well as they do because they dictate the trend several time a year, every year. That way they keep control.  The only thing that can beat trend is innovation or novelty so in other word only a new trend can stop one.  Also it‚Äôs interesting to point that a trend is most powerful just before it become popular. Because as soon as it is it‚Äôs value decrease drastically. As soon as everyone around you adopted it, everyone is already waiting for the new trend to come out. Fashion understood this very well and put in place a syst√®me that gave them the monopoly of all trend. The monopoly of ¬´¬†good taste¬†¬ª.

You know, I never saw any of 5gums advertising. I did like the gum though. The packaging was very nice and I liked the taste of their their gums. However, we have stopped buying them because there is too few of them in a pack. My family buys a lot of gum, but only in large doses. The reason is quite simple. We only chew gum when in the car. And if you chew gum every time you get into the car, you will use up the gum quite fast. We also tend to take double the intended amount, which basicly means that we exhaust our supply double as fast as someone, who would only take one gum. And so we prefer large packs of gum, which 5gum just wasnt.

Funny story. In 2014-2015ish i used to run some larger twitter accounts, usually parody type accounts. Well, one day I created a parody account that was just "What it feels like to chew 5 gum" along side some relevant, meme-like photo. The account was accually growing well, reaching about 50,000 followers in a month or so. Then, randomly, I got a C&D in the mail from Wrigley saying I had to take the account down lol. I always thought it was kinda silly on their part as the account wasnt malicious and if anything it was just free advertising, though I suppose they dont want a random account branded to look like their own, becoming popular if they dont have control over the content.
Marketing was so good that I only buy that gum to this day.  Business/marketing strategy was and still is insane.

I feel like I need to defend Razer a little bit. Yes, the rgb face mask was kinda cringe, but they made a mockup as a complete joke, and people were so insistent in their rabid "MAKE IT A REAL PRODUCT" posts and emails, that they would have been dumb to not do it. They sold out almost immediately too, and they had active filters on them, so despite the rgb, they worked better than the masks everyone was wearing. As for throwing their logo on things and jacking up the price.....I don't think they alone can bear the ridicule for doing that, that's kinda how brand collabs work. Drink from Mcdonalds: $2. Drink from Mcdonalds with Lisa from Genshin Impact on it? $4. 14:32 Actually, there is some science to using peppermint to improve focus, but it's not instantaneous. I actually used to chew Rain or Cobalt while studying. I eventually chewed Cobalt exclusively for studying, because Rain was my favorite and I didn't want to associate it with studying.  Point is, it's like meditative breathing or mnemonics. The idea is that you take a very strong smell or flavor, peppermint and orange are the most popular ones, and you associate that with positive momentum in whatever you're trying to accomplish. Like whitenoise machines being used for work or sleep, or gym music. It's meditative conditioning to help you remember or focus on something you otherwise wouldn't want to do. And it worked great! I can still remember the algebra formulas I studied when I went through a pack of Rain and Swerve simultaneously. üòÇ

So I was in 6th grade when 5 took off. I never saw an ad for it ever cause we didn't get cable.   But my class loved 5 because of the colored wrappers. We figured out you could peel the colored foil off the paper and then redecorate your super cringe planner with a collage of the foil colors because it stuck to the texture of the planners. People who had parents who were willing to buy them a bunch of gum would show up to school with the new color and people would flock to ask for the wrappers. I remember when gold and black came out lol. People who are good at peeling the foil in bigger pieces got a lot of attention to peel wrappers for other people in exchange for the actual gum  We literally cared about the wrappers more than the gum lol

16:28 Hear me out: Putting B vitamins in chewing gum is lowkey genius. Vitamin B12 absorption requires binding to proteins in *saliva* which shield it from degradation by stomach acid and gastric enzymes. This means using chewable supplements, such as gummies or **drumroll** chewing gum leads to far more efficient absorption of B12. Thank you for coming to my TED talk.  Sauce: https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminB12-HealthProfessional/#:~:text=The%20process%20starts%20in%20the,binding%20protein%20in%20the%20saliva.

MW2 lobby, 5 gum, fantastic
I made a lot of money in middle school buying bulk packs of 5 gum and bite size airheads at my local Sam‚Äôs Club. I‚Äôd resell them at a quarter per stick of gum or bite size airhead. People had absolutely no problem paying that and a lot of times they‚Äôd give me a dollar for two sticks of gum and two airheads.   The airheads made good money, but the gum was really the best. I‚Äôd bring a dozen packs of gum a day and leave school with $30. Each pack sold for $3.75 and I got them for well under a dollar, it was like $20 for a 24 pack of them. They were compact and extremely easy to sell, plus the gum had nearly universal demand. Everyone wants gum.   The important part is to not sell anyone the full pack because that breaks the illusion that they‚Äôre getting a good deal. If you‚Äôre selling them a single stick and the price is a quarter, it‚Äôs very easy for them to not even think about the price because a quarter is so little, but if you allow them to buy the whole pack for $3.75 then it‚Äôs easy for them to realize that you‚Äôre making money off them because they‚Äôve bought packs of gum before so they‚Äôre familiar with what the retail price should be.  Obviously they could just do the math in their head to figure out how much you make off the whole pack, but you‚Äôd be surprised how often people won‚Äôt do that when the price is low enough.   What I learned from that experience is that as a salesman, the main thing you have to overcome isn‚Äôt your customer‚Äôs desire to keep their money, you instead have to overcome their pride. The thing that will keep people from buying more than anything is if they know that you‚Äôre making a lot off them, because at that point pride kicks in and that pride will prevent the sale more than their wallet will.

only time I've felt the need to leave a corrective comment but, uhhhh bro. chewing gum has a long history and studies connecting it to improved focus. the US military has pushed on it a dozen times during conflicts to improve focus. it's also probably why nicotine gum was chosen early as an ideal form of the product as a generally-accepted anti-smoking aid for people addicted to the stimulant that is nicotine. great video, but you seemed to baselessly dismiss gum's focus benefits more than a few times. a short read on the subject: https://unwritten-record.blogs.archives.gov/2019/09/24/chewing-gum-in-wwi-photos/ (yes I was a diehard 5 kid for lol's, but just enjoy gum as a high-energy, low focus smoker-tryna-quit)

Ok, I will be honest, the ‚Äúgum helps concentration‚Äù part reminded me of when I used to chew gum while on casual ‚Äúspirited‚Äù nighttime drives on mountain roads. I think what made it work wasn‚Äôt that it had anything special added, but that it was more or less a type of ‚Äúfidget‚Äù device in a way. I typically clench my teeth when I‚Äôm focused on something, so this allowed me to have something to keep my jaw muscles occupied, making that less of a distraction. I really don‚Äôt remember what brand I used to chew though. I WAS AT THE OWNERS HOUSE!!! I was sent out to repair William Wrigley Jrs smoke alarm(ADT) When I got to his home he opened his door and said. Come back in one hour, I'm thinking who does this guy think he is? I called my boss and he said, That's William Wrigley jr and you're waiting an hour! After the repair I was lucky enough to sit on his couch and talk to him,  The living room walls were lined with photos of famous race horses, Some how we got on the subject of the CUBS(Wrigleyville) And I said it was too bad they sold them, He quickly reminded me he still owned the gum, I let out a giant "oh my god" It Never dawned on me Wrigleyville baseball was also Wrigley gum! He never tipped me even though I was struggling, When I got home the news had a special on, "Illinois top richest billionaires"  Who was on?! William Wigley jr, Oprah Winfrey.... I Screamed! I was just on his couch!

So "who chews gum while gaming?" the answer is autistic people or at least this autistic person. I'm almost always chewing something, either my chewllery, gum, or basically anything else I can get my hands on as I find it very soothing and I found that if I didn't actively take steps to fill that need that it would typically result in me finding something to eat whenever there was a drop in the dopamine from gaming such as during loading screens or when I get tilted which results in me over eating and putting on a bunch of weight. I mean I definitely don't think this is the case for even most autistic people but for some of us chew a lot of gum, personally I go through about 1-2 packs of gum per day. I'm almost always chewing gum but particularly when I'm at home playing video games.  But also no.... if I can hear you chewing gum you're doing it wrong and I don't want that shit in my ear. I would also think that even the loudest gum chewer wouldn't be able to get it through any modern noise suppression.

You look like agent pena from Narcos
Another strength about the original campaign was that it was internationally appealing. The actors were diverse, the setting was surreal and ambiguous, not setting it in any specific place or time, the only language featured in the ad was the product name and the slogan, spoken by a disembodied voice. That meant it was easy to dub or subtitle and even if you didn't understand the language for some reason, the images spoke for themselves. The ads like the "no regrets" campaign may be memorable, but they're also so extremeky specifically tied to geography and history. People from different countries who face different kinds of challenges might find it difficult to relate to an eldery black American man or Chinese woman... which is why I'm pretty sure it never ran outside the US (atleast I've never seen it), already limiting its effectiveness for a global brand like Wrigleys.
I haven't watched yet, but that is one epic thumbnail and title

Nah, there's no "returning to form" for 5 gum. That initial over-the-top Stimulate Your Senses campaign got attention because it was novel and in your face, but it was really that specific time period that made it work so well ‚Äì they could never lean back into that and get any traction again, it was a cultural phenomenon with a limited shelf life. IMO the first campaign that you so prefer had no more to do with chewing gum than the Life Happens in 5 campaign, which I personally feel is less forced (although still cringe). I think those rites of passage featured in the Life Happens in 5 stuff are way more relatable than the first campaign. 5 gum being the Axe body spray of gum is a REALLY good take, though lol. When you think about it 5 has always been a lie, how the fuck does it involve more senses than basically any other candy, gum, or food? Once you get it in your mouth basically you've got a taste and some smell

5 had so many identity crisis simply because of Wrigley wanting to standardize their products, thus making a packaging and/or marketing mistake 1 or 2 times, leading to a loss in market share, all while the market demand was declining. Execs freaked out a had two paths, invest and attempt to break out of the rut, or blame the rut solely on declining market demand. One cost money, and the other didn‚Äôt.  They surely blamed lack of demand, cut back across the board, and from then on it was a never ending game of follow the decline, where they keep cutting back more and more and more, in order to remain ‚Äúprofitable‚Äù all while blaming the market.

You missed an interesting time in the 5 gum history, which was the long running ARG they ran around 2012-2013.  There was an unraveling story about the facility shown in the 5 gum commercials with weekly puzzles and hidden clues that required purchasing more 5 gum packs to acquire codes to unlock.  In the end there was a hunt in (I believe 5) major cities around the US to win undisclosed prizes and some kind of statue.  I was actually really into it at the time and was buying ridiculous amounts of 5 gum for codes.  Kinda a smart campaign to be honest.
In middle school 5gum immediately made you cool. When the released the Black Edition we all went crazy because it tasted like fruity pebbles.  It became a highly traded commodity.

Weirdly, chewing gum when gaming is actually a pretty good idea. Firstly, as long as you weren't raised by absolute mongrels, you don't smack your lips when chewing it, so the sound issue is fabricated. Secondly, before even talking about vitamins and tea extracts and such, we need to take one fact into account that gum manufacturers missed: chewing gum increases brain functionality. So the base product "chewing gum" is already an enhancer. That limits your ability to feast on crappy Doritos. I don't actually see any downsides.

Not to give marketing ideas to megacorporations, but as someone who grew up with stuff like Pokemon and Bionicle, a big factor of 5's appeal that I'm surprised they never caught on to is the collectability. Like the gum was good and I wouldn't've bought it if it wasn't, and they offered more flavors than other brands at the time, but honestly the main reason I wanted to buy it was cuz I liked the packaging. I'd look at it and imagine the flavors as different elements, and what it'd look like to have powers based on them, which is also why I liked that there were so many flavors. And honestly the emphasis on the senses in the marketing added to this, it was like they were trying to imbue you with the essence of the flavor or "element" of the gum.
At the 17 minute mark you ask who chews gum while gaming. Esports players. Specifically because they aren‚Äôt allowed to have liquids or food near the computers. So it kinda works for that angle. Niche but.. thought out.

All of your commentary is very surface level. You criticize the gamer angle because "who chews gum while playing games?" while also implying that Doritos and Mountain Dew are somehow a time tested gaming accessory. Except that you only associate them with gaming because of gamer-centric advertising... even when eating Doritos while gaming is arguably worse of a descision than chewing gum.  You definitely have skill when it comes to editing, (although, in my opinion, it's a little over the topüôÉ) so you absolutely have the ability to present an idea in an interesting way. And of course, I'm just one person and you really don't have to please everyone.

Dog I'm not even 10 seconds in, you look exactly like Pedro Pascal
5 used to have one of the longest lasting spearmint flavors which is all I wanted at the time. I couldn't realize tell you when it just didn't scratch that itch but it just didn't seem to hold the flavor as long after a while.
Oooh, a random video the algorithm feeds me that I had a bit of a connection to, in a way.  "Life happens in 5"...  That's like...  How long a stick of it lasted anyways, and became a running joke we ran into on the street team during the pre-launch campaign.  As someone who was part of the street crew doing the initial launch of 5 Gum in four select cities in Canada, there definitely was a LOT of initial catering to the hype engine.  We're talking Halo 2 levels of hype, but dialed up even more, and way more disappointing.  For the first two months, the goal was to basically get it's image tied with places that were considered edgy - namely skate shops, as if they were trying to target that demographic (and those at Hot Topic, but we didn't have such in Canada at the time).  Effectively, we worked with the shops to have it as something they could offer to a perk to customers as freebies with their purchases, and a number of companies absolutely loved it (hey, free merch?  Who doesn't want free extra things at a place you were going to spend money at anyways?)  There was also the street level team, which focused more on giving out packets that were arguably three quarters waste to anyone on the street who was even remotely curious.  It had a website on the package, a pair of 3d super cheap branded glasses, but the only thing people really cared about was the stick of gum within the package.  This campaign focused specifically on the "popular clubbing areas", so was pretty much Thurs/Fri/Sat.  By the second week, the street team would actively be approached by people, but the biggest question we had wasn't what the glasses were for, but what flavours we had with us.  It's been too long and I can't remember if it was Flare or Cobalt that were the two launch ones - all I remember is having to figure out what to do with something like fifty cases of gum once the promo was done, and ten cases of the promo single stick ones.  Oh yeah, and how reception would change from people as to which flavour we had on us.  We very quickly started focusing on one flavour over the other depending on the areas we were in (one area preferred Cobalt, the other Flare).  They even had a tie-in event with some big name dj's at the time for some big event, but stupidly told the street promo the wrong location, so we spent EIGHT WEEKS telling people it was one thing, while the promo team for the event was referencing the actual, and once posters went up we were all "uh, hey Wrigley, where is this actually being held?  Yeah, it's in the same area, but many have a MASSIVE beef with the club you've told us it's at".  So the last week and a half of the promo we were scrambling to try and get correct information out.  Anyways, day of event comes out, and it was a good event, but the best comment we wound up getting back from staff?  "It's nice that everyone has fresh breath", and while we had packed enough gum to practically keep an entire army stocked (or so it felt, I was literally shipped fifty bulk cases literally for the event), it didn't take long for literally everyone to wind up having gum.  Also, like yeah, let's target teenagers, and stores teens shop at, but then hold the launch event at an 18+ joint.  We got so much feedback that was disappointed because they wanted to see the djs involved, but they were underaged.  Cringiest part of it all though?  We as a street team we were supposed to take "edgy" photos of people enjoying the gum, and it was just so difficult to do for most of our team.  Sure, some people did participate, but the biggest issue with all of it was we were literally bugging people on the street trying to push a product, and the only real effective tactic that was working with the average person was going with a quick five second contact approach (one team member literally would just ask "Hey, want some free gum?" and offer a package).  Oh yeah, for some reason they felt the best way for the street promo team to be doing all of this was in deep cut v-neck shirts too.  Yup, even the guys.  They were VERY comfortable shirts, but man that cut was just so weird for the two guys involved, and I felt bad for the women (who very quickly asked if they could wear clothing close enough, to which I was more than happy to oblige, because I'm not kidding about how deep that cut was on the v neck - we're talking a decent amount of cleavage wound up showing).  Paid well though, but it quickly taught me that yeah, live marketing is a weird culture, and I said screw it, and went back to working in warehouses.  Those commercials were pretty epic when they came out though.  Not as epic as Canada's "crisis identity" ones (Why be you, when you can be me), but still.  They had a nice twist to things for the mid to late 2000's.  They sure faded to obscurity in really short order around here though, seemingly dying out after just a few years.  Was kind of amazed to hear they still technically exist, even if just as a token thing with the most ragged on green branded company out there.

Lmfao... my guy, what do you think energy drinks are made of? üòÇ It's literally just normal soda with extra caffiene, B6 and B12, and usually some combo of ginseng, green tea, and/or guarana and taurine.  So basically caffiene and B vitamins are the only ingredients that have proven stimulant-like effects, and the rest are ancient herbal medicines that either contain caffiene or have some *supposed* "restorative" or "replenishing" effects. 5 Gum was the shit back in the day. I loved the orange one. There was a guy in our class buying 5 gum online or something and selling it at school. He had to be ordering it online, since he had some flavors you couldn't get in stores in Germany at the time. The original "obliterate your senses" ads just fit perfect into the time of the Matrix movies and stuff like that. 16:47  I will say, a surprising amount of people in the esports corner of gaming chew gum. There's a sort-of psychological element to it where it keeps your brain busy while you're in the heat of the moment, which can be good for your nerves while playing in a tournament. That said, gamers *do not* give a shit about who they get gum from and the vitamin mumbo jumbo has nothing to do with the actual reason they chew gum, so "gamer gum that helps you focus better" was still doomed from the start.
The stuff became it's own meme, with countless examples of a video clip that starts with "this is how chewing 5 gum feels like" and then something like a screaming dog or a wasted dude who smashes his head against a wall. That. They could have used that.

To me, 5 gum's advertising feels inextricably linked to the Microsoft original X-Box advertising, and that whole era of design for young men/teenage boys. So nostalgic, and all broadly inspired by The Matrix with some touches drawn from Geiger and Alien. Very interesting to look back on it now and see how the aesthetic's dropped right out of the cultural milieu.

the thing with inaccesibility in shops is actually low-key genius if done properly (not this case).  See they market the product as "GAMER" Product in social media to gain wide coverage. Then pay some youtubers absolute dogshit amount to market it on his channel. YTbers, especially not the top 10 ones, will sign the deal. Imagine you are a YTber and get a deal with Wrigleys. THE Wrigleys. 90% of people will take it. Then the YT person either provides the link to buy the product straight from the manufacturer, or will sell it in his small merch store. If he manages to sell a "limited overpiced edition cause YT on lid", even better.  So your manufacturing costs are minimal cause you already sell the same product. MArketing costs are minimal due to shitty deals with YT people. And distribution cost is minimal because you either ship directly to buyer or you dump it on other people to sell it. Its evil, but genius. You bypass the deals with large shops, the quality controls in transport, the large haul fees, all that shit and you dump it on someone lower.  You dont even have to make the production large, just ramp up the price and call it exclusive

The funny thing, is that with the initial attempt to advertise gamers they could have had a happy ending.  5 did great with intensity associations, and gaming can be shown as intense, it's the same demographic.  But what did they do?  Name it Respawn and show videos of people at computers...terrible choice.  Not only is having to respawn a low point when gaming and doesn't give excited feelings, but all they did was show people sitting.  Anyone with a brain could have marketed it as an instant success.  Rename it Killstreak (even better since it works with the number 5), and in a commercial after the gamer puts it in his mouth cut to inside the game and have pure action sequences that are over the top until he celebrates victory.  Boom, instant sales.  Instead they made it as low energy as possible and failed yet again.

I don't think chewing gum lost market share to breath mints, I think both industries' sales plummeted due to less of the target demographic smoking cigarettes and taking up vaping. People were only buying gum and mints to cover up the smell of cigarettes on their breath and now they feel like they don't have to with sweeter or odourless vapes.
It was radical. RAD. Then it just kinda became... every other gum. So I wouldn't exactly bring back this brand in small or big capacity, but... I would, since they're all basically the same thing, bring out A NEW brand, so that it's not associated with 5 Gum, and it can be... whatever it wants to be.

Check the studies about that.  Actualkly chewing bubble gum can make you also more chill, relax and thus more effective in a difficult task, as you are less prone to a tunnel vision and do see more solutions, Also check the studies bout that topic.  So chewing gum in a game DOES improve your skills. And NO it has nothing to do with intgirients, so the comparison between a "power drink" and gum is not appropriate, as both work totally different.

15:47 Old Razer was so good though!!  Their OG Black Mamba keyboard and Naga mouse were awesome!  I even have my old Tartarus!  But then...the lights changed.  It went from green to blue, then green, then back to blue again, until suddenly _RGB ALL THE THINGS_  and I do mean EVERYTHING (even chairs!)    Even that was okay, for a while, but they just didn't stop.   Suddenly Razer's got 20+ keyboards (just keyboards) and they're making full blown laptops!  (Which ranged from ridiculous to pointless).  The product lines kept expanding (so did the prices) and suddenly I get this feeling that everything is all lights and no substance.   Razer had become the Apple of Gaming.    And just like Apple, they got rich and their brains rotted out.  Idk if they got bought out or something but once they made a touchscreen laptop?  It was all downhill.   Product quality started dropping drastically.  The required software to run it got more bigger, glitchy-er, & heavier.  It started spying on you (and "optimizing" your game settings??), split into 3 pieces, stopped working, and was always running?!  Just like iTunes: it doesn't work, but good luck getting rid of it.    I look up one day, and Razer's making headphones with cat ears on them.   F*cking _cat ears_ y'all!   Razer always sucked at audio, so I knew they were trash but *_really_* ???   The Great Pandering was complete.  Everything Razer made had become poorly made crap.  I do still have a keyboard of theirs, the Ornata, and my OG Naga mouse to play MMOs with, but I probably won't buy anything from them ever again.  The software alone is enough reason to stay away.  I don't wanna sign into a keyboard account so Razer can log my keystrokes and sell them to God knows who!    Sad story, bro.  So much greatness turned into equally massive pile of üêïüí©

Honestly, I think the fall of gum in general is due to kids being taught from a young age since the 2000's or so that they aren't allowed to have it. Parents didn't want kids to chew gum in case it somehow gets in the carpet, or hair, or other places it shouldn't. Schools didn't want you to have gum because it was so commonplace to just stick it underneath your desk. The problem with gum is how it gets disposed of afterwards. If it goes anywhere but the trash, it's a problem. Maybe even in the trash it's a problem but I'm no expert on landfills. Breath mints and the like are much easier as there's no disposal aspect of it. They taste the same, but with one less step.
On that last part:  Chewing gum is a stimulating and has obvious ties to focus just in the masticulation of the chewy substance. Its like "chewing? Must be eating then, so I guess I'm not starving, I am now not thinking about survival and can focus on other tasks".   Additonally there is a massive difference between a Nootropic substance such as root, mushroom, and plants extracts, and the energizing effects of caffeine. Basically, drinking and energy drink could actually do less to focus your mind on a game than an energy drink depending on whats in them. So yes, despite how it might seem to you, RAZER and Wrigley's did in fact make a useful product for gamers. Honestly, there is very little besides crass marketing coming out at the same time as heartfelt marketing that Wrigley's did that was at all strange or wrong. They wanted to target a demographic, thought of ways to do so, and did so. Nothiong wrong with that. Also, the same goes for RAZER. Nice video, but I find it strange just how forced all the criticism, or indirect criticism was, try to tone that down or be a bit more on the mark with the commentary in the future.

Admired the boxes. Never tried. I think maybe your wrap up at the very end both hits the nail and utterly misses the mark. I bet that what happened was people bought gum. And people found out what it was like to chew gum. It's like... chewing gum. EVEN IF it comes in a nice outdated box.  They could have a good launch back when nobody knew what it was like to chew THIS gum and with enough hoopla people (note : inexperienced kids) might think this was different. And try it. But then they learned. It's gum. Gum is so inherently lame we have "walk and chew gum".  I remember when squirty gum came out. What was it like to chew cum gum? After the first 0.25 seconds, it was like chewing gum.  I remember when Hubba Bubba came out. What was it like to chew Hubba Bubba? It was almost like chewing gum but a bit... fluffier. For five minutes. Then it became like chewing gum.  Look, chewing gum is so banal they piled extra meanings on the term in order to bulk it out. chewing gum : gum for chewing chewing gum : the act of masticating gum for chewing  AND masticating itself comes from mastic. Proto-gum.

"...we can't rush B.." ... *Counter Strike mind remembers* ... you literally brought up my childhood in a nutshell.
5 Gum came at a time when the image of gum had lost most of its shock value. It was no longer seen by most of society as an idle, pointless, or uncivil display of bad manners, nor as a playful act of youth rebellion, nor something that teen movies would use to show that a kid was a rebel and/or fun-loving. Tim Burton‚Äôs Willy Wonka turned Violet Beauregard into a record-obsessed hyper-competitive overachiever, not just a gum enthusiast‚Ä¶ because gum, really? If anything, the sound puts some people off‚Ä¶ but closing your mouth goes a long way. Even some schools would allow gum in the 2000s, and the rule was up to the teachers in my high school. In college? If you have gum, you‚Äôd better share it!   Gum was no longer a ‚Äúbad habit‚Äù, or something that‚Äôs ‚Äúat least better than smoking‚Äù, but a personal choice ‚Äì a sensory stim, a way to freshen your breath/teeth, or just something to chew on‚Ä¶ yet 5 somehow managed to bring back the ‚Äúinnocent rebel‚Äù image just a little longer.

However the scientists and such are real but also being projected into these virtual spaces to observe what are actual tests of the limits of the simulation technology, specifically they're stress tests of the "man-machine interface" at the very heart of the technology and are very important to it's continued safe functioning. Also, the experiences are desirable and there's no possibility of danger, though they're not guaranteed or even totally designed to be enjoyable an "extreme sports" like culture and attitude has developed around them ensuring the positive attitude of the test subjects that actually apply to become a one. Chewing gum has actually become more popular for esports, specifically at higher levels of CS. There's multiple tier 1 CS pros that chew gum during officials, you just have to tune your mic to it. It's a way to minimize ADHD/nerves/ticks ingame, like how Stewie2K would permanently move his mouse when he was holding angles for long periods of time, but physical rather than in-game.

I mean, there's a really limited acceptable flavor profile for chewing gum, and upping the intensity of acceptable tastes is just going to mean that a stick of gum will start to taste boring that much faster.

I remember in the late 2000's when 5 gum came out. It didn't matter how lame, nerdy, poor, or generally uncool you were, all it took to jump to the top of the cool list was to pull out a pack of 5 gum in the classroom and pass a few pieces around. People would crowd up and offer anything they had, especially food, just to get a few pieces. Monster energy drinks, Axe body spray, and 5 gum were the epitome of coolness in high school.

Here's the bigger problem: People don't like gum. As a kid, I felt like there was some kind of brain washing to convince everyone that "Hey! These overbearing flavors that will make the entire room smell like some nauseating variant on mint are great! I can't wait to chew the flavor out of it for 30 seconds and then be left with a wad of inedible gross sticky rubber that I need to find a trash can for!" From the looks of things, I was right, since I hardly see anybody my age actually use gum for anything ever. If they were smart, they'd go from gum to an actual candy that dissolves in your mouth, but I suspect they're not going to do that.

There is a huge difference between bubble gum and chewing gum.  Bubble gum tends to be stretchier to make it easier to blow bubbles with while chewing gum tends to be chewier to help promote saliva production.    Chewing gum while playing games could help give you focus regardless of the additives in the gum as the repetitive mindless action of chewing in the background of your brain helps to keep you focused on the task at hand.  A vast majority of people chewing on chewing gum also tend not to make obnoxious noises with it (i.e. they chew with their mouth closed and pause chewing when they want to talk).  Personally I tend to listen to fast paced EDM when I am playing fast paced FPS games as it helps keep my brain on edge with the beat along with keeping my brain focused on the task at hand and chewing gum would likely have the same kind of effect on me.  5 gum going down the gaming gum route would actually be in their wheelhouse if they kept their original marketing strategy but the completely random marketing attempts in between the "Stimulate your senses" and whatever the gaming gum slogan is has really muddied up their market niche.  They could have easily made commercials that tied in well with the original ad campaign too to help reinforce the "How it feels to chew 5 gum" marketing slogan.
"Hey, what should we name the peppermint one?"  "Mmm, how about we name it after a lethal poison that also gives no clue what it tastes like."

I was introduced to the brand ages back when a friend just gave me a piece and didn't really explain anything. I was surprised by how long it lasted, which is the main reason I don't chew gum - the flavor is gone almost instantly. That wasn't the case with 5 Gum, and looking back I find it pretty funny how they actually had what other brands claim (long-lasting flavor) but instead they ignore it entirely to chase trends.  I also hadn't seen the 'stimulate your senses' ads until I was already in the midst of a 5 Addiction, so it didn't play much of a role. They also didn't seem that unusual for the time, albeit a strange choice for a gum brand. Definitely noticed they've been getting much more tame over recently years but man... I didn't know their past was quite this indecisive.

The Yungblud collaboration is weird. It's basically a 180 on who they're trying to market to. Teen boys don't like him in the same way they didn't like Justin Bieber, Leonardo DiCaprio or any number of assorted boy bands over the years. He's not very good and the girls like him more than they like the boys, so the boys resent him. No chance they'd buy gum with his face on it, even if it's just for the purposes of attempting to seduce a girl. The embarrassment of carrying a packet of gum with his face on it or being associated with his marketing campaign is not worth it to them. As for teen girls, I don't think they'd continue to buy the gum once the endorsement deal is over, since it's not very good gum, so it's not really gaining repeat customers, just a temporary influx of funding.

Killer video sir.
Only about half way through the video so I‚Äôm not sure if it gets covered later on, I believe a big cause of the fall of the popularity of gum was the fall in the popularity of traditional cigarettes. Gum has always been pseudo-tied to cigarettes. Because of the amount of saliva produced by chewing gum it was the better option in comparison to mints. Once vaping became more available gum became much less necessary for a large portion of consumers. Young people especially boys and young men the age range originally targeted by 5 gum were the first to transition to vaping and remove the need for gum from their everyday use. With this in mind it would make a little more sense why 5 gum shifted their marketing in an attempt to reach consumers who still smoked traditional cigarettes (edit: and as the commenters below suggests, people looking to stop smoking) because that was probably the highest population of daily gum chewers the biggest chunk of money in the market at the moment.
Chewing gum was somewhat popular as a replacement for chew tobacco, which was also popular with mechanics and similar professions that required heavy concentration. Chewing gum while focusing on something was popular in media for that reason. It keeps your mind active or something? idk. I used to chew gum regularly when I needed to focus. Seeing you so bewildered by the idea of chewing gum while playing games made me confused, but I forgot that a lot of people play games in voice chat with people now, so I can see how that practice fell out of favor, haha
I remember being a kid in 2000s trying to ask my mom what they were even trying to advertise
Their flavors always had a sort of "sting" to them that really drove home the cold, industrial look of the advertising and packaging. It was like you got some cologne on your gum but for some reason it was actually favorable. Losing sight of the strange futuristic industrial branding of it really was a terrible mistake.

Even if B vitamins might be helpful for concentration, I can't imagine chewing gum is the best delivery system. It is the one food product you never actually supposed to eat. You just chew it and I guess get some of the juices. So unlike an energy drink, which you can just assume whatever you put into the can goes into the consumer, you will likely have to overload the gum with way too much B vitamin since a lot of it will likely get left in the gum when you throw it out. But then again, if you do that, I'd be worried that the weird kid that always swallows the gum might get an overdose since they actually get the full amount in the gum. So at that point, it is safer to put in only a token amount that never has any real effect when consumed normally.

The "how it feels to chew 5 gum" slogan is part of internet culture. People make memes with it. Back in the day, if your brand became a verb, you "made it". If your product becamt the generalization for a family of products, you "made it". Nowadays, if what you do is so nuts and over the top, the internet incorporates you into its meme culture, you basically made it (although to a lesser degree maybe than with the examples of back in the day). And instead of jumping on the meme bandwagon and trying to re-invigorate their "how it feels to chew 5 gum" thing, they did...whatever their new ads were supposed to be. Their ads looked like that old guy in a baseball cap and with a skateboard walking up to these young adults like "Hey fellow kids".

Part of it is the sheer meme power. People made "how it feels to chew 5Gum" meme edits of all sorts of stuff. Literally the internet was making commercials for Wrigley for free by injecting memetic clips in where the usual over the top shenanigans in the actual ads happened, and nobody batted an eye because there was a viral marketing power to it. Companies would kill for that these days.

Unironically they had us in the first half.  As a guy who chewed 5 gum, the entire appeal was feeling maybe 5% more tingle on your toung for about half a minute, and they definitely 1000% should have took that, and kept running with it, same thing with the advertisement,  Communicate how the gum is *supposed* to make you feel, even if at the end of the day it's not that special, because *feeling* something special, unique, or intense is almost universally appealing and is something that could pretty easily be connected to a snack, something that at the end of the day is a sensory experience.  It wasn't the fact that it was edgy like sky diving or political issues that made it appealing, it was the promise and anticipation of feeling literally anything unique when their other brands where promising fresh breath and a smile, something as appealing as toothpaste.

"simply having an energy drink would be infinitely more effective [for energy/focus than B vitamins and green tea extract in gum]" yes, it would also be infinitely more effective at contributing (if not causing) weight gain (esports are not actual physical sports so there's no physical activity), contributing to addiction/dependency on it due to the amount of caffeine, sugar and other things that contribute to that sort of thing, heart conditions due to the caffeine and the taurine and the other excessive things in there, plus numerous other risks and problems simply because energy drinks are a complete waste if you're gonna drink it like it's soda or beer and literally let the energy go to waste; you'll be f-ing with your adrenaline/epinephrine response and stuff too and many people do not stop at just one, so the problems pile on.  if the gum just has normal gum things and a bit of vitamin B (pretty much impossible to have "too much" because any excess just gets excreted in your urine and doesn't cause harmful effects, source: family doctor telling my mother to take 2000 [units, idk if mcg or mg or iu or what anymore] daily + a week of research from myself in relation to depression) and there's probably less than what you'd get even from a basic multivitamin + green tea extract for a bit of caffeine, like, a super tiny amount most likely.  the whole "gamer gum" thing is ridiculous, i agree, but if you're gonna compare it to an energy drink, specifically in relation to video games (A.K.A. sitting on Uranus at a desk) then the gum wins 1,000,000%. energy drinks should be used for physical activity and even then it's questionable. there's a reason those things aren't supposed to be sold to anyone under 16 in many places (18 in some) and why some are straight up banned from some countries

I‚Äôve struggled with ADHD that I only recently got diagnosed, and what I‚Äôve found is that I get distracted less if I have some stimulus in the background, like gum or music.   Before that I‚Äòd constantly get distracted even while doing things that I enjoyed, like gaming, and I‚Äôd have to put in more active focus which made them less enjoyable. It made me pretty depressed towards the end of my teenage years to find that all my hobbies now felt like work. Gum has been a nifty little hack to help me passively focus and enjoy games again.  That being said, I‚Äôd chew almost anything other than 5gum. The flavour on most gums evaporates in minutes, so all your left with is the sensory experience, and 5gum is just too thin and flimsy. I prefer bubblegum, it‚Äôs a more interesting texture.  Maybe they should be marketing to people with ADHD instead? They‚Äôre all over TikTok at the moment, it‚Äôs trendy right now.

I've been playing CS since 1.6 both competitively and casually. The common advice I've heard for trying to deal with nerves when you're in a match is to chew gum. The consensus behind it was that chewing gum tricks your mind into thinking that you're eating and that calms nervousness somehow. I've tried it out myself and it does work sometimes. If you've been following CS esports for a while, you might have even noticed some pros chewing gum while they're in their matches (Twistzz being one usual suspect for this). So the segment at 15:07 slamming Respawn Gum for being "completely off base" and completely exaggerating the sound you can make chewing gum rubbed me the wrong way. I understand that you're trying to entertain here, but beating up a strawman isn't fun to watch. Yes, I understand that it doesn't completely represent the entire identity of "gaming" and that Wrigley's was probably leaning a bit too hard into the gaming angle. But acting like the decision had no basis behind it is kind of icky tbh.

Wow, what a throwback... I remember LOVING this stuff back in the day. I was certainly the target demographic for it. As a teenager I was always carrying one of these around, it made me feel all cool and edgy and epic. It was my favorite gum and I was always chewing some, even at school.  Then, when they launched the truth or dare campaign, I felt that tone shift and absolutely hated it. I was so mad and disappointed that I refused to buy the gum as much as I craved it, because reading the wrappers made me feel stupid and pandered to. I didn't wanna be seen with it. It was embarrassing. I remember going around to different stores desperately looking for old packages that didn't have the truth or dare stuff on them.   Then I injured my jaw and just never chewed gum again. But hey, I'm just glad to know that I wasn't alone in my disappointment and that their downfall wasn't just something I was imagining.

For the algorithm
This is a weirdly high quality video for an advertisement posturing as a documentary. But the points made about techniques, while generally accurate for what the company is doing, are definitely not the first time these techniques have been put on TV. And presenting the product as targeting "an entirely new age of consumer", not only is targeting youth the cornerstone of successful business in a capitalist economy, but even these specific buzzwords have already been used to butter up the consumers at least as far back as the late '90s.  So, sorry, I am not fooled. It's not a documentary, it's an ad. And I don't like to let ads influence my feelings on products. My stance on 5 Gum when I arrived was that it is decent market-standard quality and price, the packaging is highly elegant and fairly wasteful, the basic advertisement campaigns are the same fairly neutral high-budget high-action psychedelic and/or sports-focused stuff they did for gum, candy, soda, and all sorts of other unhealthy consumables all the time back in the '90s. And I leave with the same stance.

Dude. I remember the days when a new flavor of 5 Gum coming out was a genuine event. In Canada we got new flavors later than the US did, or sometimes didn't get them at all. If you went down to the states and brought back a flavor none of the other kids could get their hands on you were instantly the coolest kid in the class and EVERYONE wanted a piece. And the thing is, the product actually lived up to the marketing. 5 Gum had tons of flavor and they all tasted really good. It was cool, and it deserved to be cool. It was a BIG deal. And now it's all but gone. I haven't seen one mention of it in years outside of the occasional throwback meme making fun of the marketing. I still see it in stores but I tend to speak of it in the past tense because its time is over. I haven't really put any thought into it until now, but it's the sad end to an era.

What I don't get is why they don't try to market gum to smokers, seeing as  gum is already rather popular among smokers. It actually solves two problems for  that demographic:  1. Bad Breath. If you are a  smoker, your  breath will always smell like cold  smoke, which is a rather unpleasent smell. Gum gets rid of  that  bad breath 2. Gum helps people to stop smoking specifically when it comes to the psychological part of the addiction as it is a ritual that can effectively  replace the  ritual that is smoking + it helps with the  nervous symptoms of withdrawal.  Another theory I have is that gum has fallen of in popularity because smoking has as well but I didn't research that. Its an interesting thought though in my opinion.

Most people chew with their mouth closed and when they need to talk or roast the enemy team you place it in the small pockets under your tounge or the side of your cheek.

Honestly, I find the 5gum pandering to gamers quite fitting. The image of intense flavour of the early marketing campaign fits the narrative of excited gamers seeking more stimulation of their senses while playing a game, and even stylistically the sleek, black and almost neon coloured design of the packaging fits into other gaming oriented brands.  Also not everybody is chewing gum with an open mouth trying to be as loud as possible like you were in the example. Hell, I work in IT Support and regularly chew gum (not 5gum, too expensive) while on the phone without any noise because I pay attention to only do so with a closed mouth and to place the gum out of the way when speaking.
17:25 Well, if you chew at the loudest possible volume, with deliberately maximized smacking and a wide open mouth, then yeah, it's gonna annoy your team mates. Try maybe keeping your mouth closed while chewing? Maybe it won't bother people then?
Hold up wait a second who chews gum AUDIBLY? I would much rather see that everyone I'm in a discord call with has chewing gum, as opposed to hearing a single person eat food ever again in my life.   Chewing gum makes a lot of sense for teens and gamers tbh. 1) improves focus which is great for tests AND games. 2) hygiene concerns & awkward teen breath moments begone. 3) you don't end up snacking on sugary or fatty stuff while sitting around all day. OH and 4) some gamers grit their teeth while gaming which can cause jaw pain, bruxism and headaches, and chewing gum helps you relax your jaw.
5 is legitimately the best gum that exists. The flavor lasts longer and is more enjoyable than any other option out there. That's all they should focus on.

Actually the mental focus thing in respawn gum isn't a stretch lol. Green tea has an amino acid derivative called L-theanine, which is synergistic with b vitamins and actually caffeine as well. Many studies show it improves mental focus. It increases the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA in the brain, which is hard to increase on it's own because it can't cross the blood brain barrier. IDK how much 5 gum has dosage wise, but if it's high enough (which i doubt it is), then yeah, could possibly work!

Amen brother
As a former drug addict, wo did lots of research on how substances affect you and how bioavailability and all that shit works: Respawn will not help you in any way whatsoever to increase your focus or reaction time. Sure, the science behind it is genuinely real and those components do have a stimulating effect on the human brain but it won't do anything for you due to two main reasons: 1. Dosage: The dosage in that little stick of gum is so low, that it will do exactly nothing. You could put Heroin in there while keeping the exact same dosage and you would feel nothing 2. Bioavailability: How you consume a substance obviously has a very high impact on how effective it will be. Oral consumption is one of the most ineffective ways to do that. With most substances, you'll be able to only absorb around 20-30%. For comparison: nasal use will allow you to absorb 60-80% at best, while shooting it directly into your bloodstream will obviously absorb 100%. But oral consumption means, that you're swallowing whatever you're taking and your stomach mucous is able to absorb the components for around 30 minutes and even this is a highly ineffective way to do any kind of substance. Chewing gum is called chewing gum, because you jus chew it, without actually swallowing it. That means, that whatever stimulating components in that gum, will only able to be absorbed by the mucous in your mouth and only for the duration of you chewing it. I couldn't even give you a percentage value on this because it's that ineffective, no one really bothered to do serious research into this. But if I had to guess, it would probably be in the single didgets, 10% at the very most. Couple that with the laughably low dosage and you can see yourself, that an actual stimulating effect, can not be achieved, by using the product as intended. It's probably not impossible though, to get an actual effect but you'd have to chew an ungodly amount of packs, stick by stick, chewing each for at least 30-45 minutes, only to get the most subtle of effects, which you would still not notice, but it technically exists (defined by the amount of whatever stimulant inside your blood per I don't even know anymore). It would take you literally the entire day of chewing gum as effectively as possible, for a doctor to confirm, that there technically was an effect, which you wouldn't even have been able to feel.  tldr: Science checks out but reality looks different

Drinking energy drinks while gaming doesnt increase your performance by itself, and it might not even do it for "something else" in the drink, depending on what you are drinking. Redbull does not increase your cognitive overall because of the caffeine or the taurine, but because of other parts of its composition, not shared by other energy drinks like monster. What it might do is prevent adnosine from lowering it if you are sleepy, and only if you are sleepy. Green tea also does not do it. FOCUS, and the "sleepiness" are two different things from cognitive ability. If you have lowered cognitive ability due to other circumstances, energy drinks wont get it up because they allow you to focus or prevent the sleepiness from adenosine working. You might faster and more consistently do the dumb stuff you do on "energy drinks", if nothing else but stimulants like Caffeine are in it. Many, MANY, publications confuse it with enhanced cognitive function. Enhanced cognitive function might even be impaired by the other side of the coin in the stimulants, which is the fact that they make you less calm and more anxious. You can know that because excessive caffeine makes you terrible at hand to eye coordination and fine motor control.  Other substances, like the mentioned vitamin B, Omega 3, and other more "lipo related" substances which also coupled with some "fat", specially with lower blood sugar, do make you more cognitive capable, because they do make you LESS ANXIOUS and MORE CALM, which is coupled with the enhancement of the operational of the nervous system, a EFFECTIVE and proper cognitive boost.  However the brands will add up on the confusion about "faster reaction" with "better reaction" and advertise a load of crap as "science".

After watching this video ive realized that i am exactly their target demographic and a 5 Gum stan.  I used to go through about 3 packs a week when trying to control my eating. It was the only gum that could actually last longer than 10 minutes in flavor, so id chew all day. And i even realized that chewing late at night when id play games with my friends kept me more awake and therefor allowed me to play better.  And the dare campaign actually was fun for my friend group, because i started chewing it around the "fill in the blanks" campaign and would complain when my friends would always ask me, so i said they could have one if they did the dare. I was 17 when 5 gum hit.  It was pretty epic. It was definitely one of the first gum brands to really get the longer lasting flavour down.  Back in the 90's gum flavour lasted for about 2 minutes and then it was just this bland rubbery blob to chew on.  But during this time every gum was still advertised as longer lasting.  So i had been primed my whole life to think this promise was just total bs.  So when i tried 5 gum i was actually pleasantly surprised that the flavour lingered a lot longer than other gums. Keeping to their old campaign of "no regrets" would have been anti-establishment and slapping consumers in the face, and encouraging deviant behavior during an international health crisis. The only safe place to go was something everyone was doing anyway: staying home and staring at screens.

It's crazy how much marketting affects product viability. I saw the adds as a kid, sure, they were cool, but you know what was cooler? Gum that came from a sleek black box and inside was a shiny wrapper, and it was a _big_ long strip rather than just a small pill shaped thing. Made it feel luxury. And the gum itself? Genuinely some of the best flavours. It wasn't just mint or different mint like other gums, or that awkward artificial fruit flavour, it genuinely tasted pretty good.  I had stopped watching TV right when the marketting changed. I was unaware they dropped Stimulate Your Senses. And gotta say, I like the red one. All this other marketting nonsense is just noise that doesn't seem to make sense to me. I buy gum when I have a breath issue, ads aren't going to change that, brand deals aren't going to change that. Sell the flavour I like and you'll get my money.  Though, as an Australian, this does explain why I've stopped seeing it. The marketting has just failed for completely arbitrary reasons.

Admittedly, after they moved on from "How it Feels to Chew 5 Gum", I...don't recall ever actually seeing any of their ads beyond that point.  What 5 really should do is go back to their roots, as you said, but also aim for the modern market. Make a product that you can chew on when you need the focus. Make gum that has a mild amount of caffeine, vitamins, and minerals, but also with a flavor that can be tasted THROUGH the act of focusing. (Like how sometimes when we're so focused on a thing we automatically eat without tasting, avoid making a flavor that can be drowned out through focus)  Make the old, good ads again, with a gaming twist. Guy in a racing chair chewing a cool, sharp mint flavor as he hits breakneck turns. Fancy puzzle game player having a citrus flavor as they manipulate a cool holographic sphere puzzle around them. Show off a spicy flavor by having a shooter player sliding past explosions off a cliff.

Is it not more accurate to say that sale of gums was always on a downward trajectory, and Five was only a temporary fix? At least that's the way I see it. Whether they stayed with their original marketing theme or not, it was eventually going to go back to its default state - decline in overall sale and trends. One gum campaign was never going to reverse the trend. You could argue that if they had stayed with the original marketing theme, they could have enjoyed a slightly longer period of delay in the inevitable downward trend, but I just don't think Wrigley could have done anything to reverse it.

I always liked 5 gum because the gum actaully kept their flavor for more than 3 minutes. Hubba bubba, doublemint, eclipse, generic bubble gum all lost flavor within 3-5 mins until im just chewing for my jawline at that point. The texture was always really soft, too, compared to other gums. It wasn't too hard upon impact and wasn't extra chewy like hubba bubba. The packaging was also very slick and ergonomic. The only thing that came close to replacing 5 was Altoids, but after a while I switched back because altoids never lasted as long. Where'd I'd eat like 5-7 altoids, I'd eat 1 stick of gum. Plus the flavors were way better than anything on the market. The mystery flavor was one of the best ever. But now all I ever see are the basic flavors like cobalt, spearmint, a sweet flavor, and some other fresh toothpaste like flavor. I may go back to altoids just so I can have more selections now.

I genuinely miss 5 "Lush" (Tropical). It was my favorite tropical gum, and no other tropical gum has quite nailed its particular flavor. Once it disappeared around 2012 I forgot about the 5 gum lineup entirely. "Respawn Tropical Punch" caught my curiosity, but the flavor fell *far* short of Lush. Kinda like how 2010's Axe "Fever" spiced citrus was my favorite body spray ever, yet it disappeared within months, and I never enjoyed another 'citrus' spray remotely as much. And once they ruined my go-to since 2008, "Essence", with an awful reformulation in 2017 I forgot about Axe entirely  Ultimately, it just stings when specific perishables I love end up getting discontinued or their existing recipes/formulations get borked... Unlike most possessions such as tech and furniture that will last decades if well cared for, once a food or other consumable stops being produced, they expire in a matter of months and become nothing but a memory; anecdotal evidence like photos and videos being the only thing that I can present to someone who never tried the item in question, and senses like smell and taste can't be communicated -- when trying to convince anyone of the greatness of a discontinued food/drink/etc, all my praises are reduced to an unhelpful "you just had to be there bro"

You chew gum when you're outside - in a time before smartphones and social media - when girls and boys could be regular humans without it being a dangerous/lawful offense. When you lived in your daily 5-man-bubble in nature, moving your body, enhancing that experience with taste that doesn't drag you down (chewing gum - and taste for your ears: music from a boombox). But today you're consuming legal drugs (cheaper, more addicting, more unhealthy sugar-replacements, social media and other socially/governly prescribed stuff), are afraid of talking to a girl that might not be interested in you (even calling her "girl" might be seen as a hate crime nowadays), government is plainly lying and destroying any chance of building/keeping up a life, you have to waste your lifetime with meaningless nothingness like you're in prison with a better skin. There are hundreds of reasons why (e.g. if born as a white male) you just wanna keep yourself save within your personal walls and numb the fear of the outside with digital and nutritional drugs. Chewing Gum - even good ones - even what-it-feels-to-chew-5-gum Chewing Gum just can't keep up with the amount of high octane/intesity stress that humans are forced to cope with, in order to squeeze control and profit out of the fear-driven behaviour, which is more easy to monitor and control using surveilance capitalism. We're chin-deep in a full on dystopia with blinding lights, thanks to the leadership of or govs across the (global) markets, showing us how much we need them to solve the problems they continously create and are. To re-nurture the soil of the market for something like 5-gum to root and grow, there has to be a way and an interest to participate in life and nature again - without fear and surveilance but with friends and freedom. We were watching Obama's inauguration in 2009 in our middle school auditorium with the whole school and I popped a piece of 5 Gum in my mouth a little before it started. The inauguration was fairly long and I wanted to toss my gum out but didn't have tissue and the teachers were yelling at kids that were trying to get up so I just kept chewing. Eventually, it turned to a paste in my mouth. I don't know what the hell happened but it became an absolutely sickening paste. I didn't want to swallow it so I spit it into my hands and wiped it all over my seat. It was such a funny and weird experience that I still remember it clearly to this day. Didn't try 5 Gum again until about a week ago. Shits good lol don't know if it still turns to paste though

Can confirm when I was a kid that those ads worked.
I spent some time in the States between 2008-2010 and, for some reason, 5 gum is one of more distinct products I still remember (along with Twizzlers and Mountain Dew). The packaging, the name, the whole style was different from what I'm used to - and also the shape of the gum, although I suppose that is a common form for gum there anyway. I'm not saying the product blew me away, I can't even remember the taste or if I liked it, but the marketing clearly worked. It was enigmatic. Especially considering that here in Finland, almost all gum has xylitol so it's seen more as a dental health thing and freshening your breath is secondary. There are definitely more edgy or just differently styled brands (for children, teens etc), but most gum comes in bigger (I mean 200g, which isn't huge, but is no stick of gum) bags and are very.. I don't know, professional looking? The one I have is literally branded as "Professional". I don't know the stats but gum seems as popular as ever here.  Funny enough, the most prominent brand of gum we have is "Jenkki" which means Yankee, and the old ads featured dirt roads and cars and jeans. Go figure.
I think the razor thing was more for people who chew gum that play video games, than people who play video games and chew gum.
One of the main reasons people stop chewing as much gum is when aspartame was added.  Once that ingredient was added sales dropped about 57% across the board and the sales team banned it on modern political thoughts.  They did not want to admit the ingredient that multiples the shelf life by years also took away the flavor.  Gum without Aspartame tastes a hundred times better to gum with it.    Gum without Aspartame sales increased by 73% alone and the majority of Gum companies have not paid attention to that fact.

The one flavor I remember most from this brand was React.  When it was first released it was *very* strongly flavored, and it was almost, but not quite, bad tasting.  But it did do something that no other gum, no other food or drink product ever accomplish.  It would immediately cure hiccups.  And not just my hiccups.  I would share a stick with anyone who had the hiccups and tell them that this gum will make them go away.  They would scoff, but take the gum, and look at me with shock (and a little horror because of the flavor) because their hiccups were gone.  The strong and almost bad flavor of React didn't go over well, I guess, it was quickly replaced with React 2 (or maybe it was React II, I can't really remember.)  This wasn't as strong, and it didn't cure hiccups, but it did taste "better."  You can no longer get either React or React 2 flavors anymore.

16:43 More specifically, who chews gum while doing e-sports? Do they think they just sit there silently playing League in front of a huge audience? That they're not constantly talking to each other about what's happening in the game?
It's shocking they they abandoned the "How it feels to chew 5 gum" considering how much it has been memed on. Search interest peaked in 2017. No idea why they just didn't keep going with that. Getting a popular meme about your product marketing (that isn't just laughing at the product - see Morbius) is a miracle to your product marketing. Notice how Flex Tape marketing doubled down on Phil Swift destroying everything?  Notice how Old Spice marketing hasn't changed too much since it found its "identity" with Terry Crews? If it ain't broken, don't fix it. Even if they wanted to go in a different edgy direction, they were probably better off simply marketing by letting popular figures have free reign (see Tim & Eric Totinos). Imagine if Eric Andre made his own 5 Gum commercial.   The marketing team at 5 Gum were given an absolute blessing and they just threw it away. With the huge marketshare Wrigley has on gum, simply talking more about the experience of chewing gum (without focusing on terrible things like the experience of chewing expired gum) subliminally increases interest in all gum consumption. They have failed to do that IMHO.

14:32 Silly me! I don't need Adderall to help with my crippling ADHD, I obviously needed CHEWING GUM
This is surreal at a few levels. Chewing gum may be one of the things I'm legit addicted to (If I'm out, and at my desk, eventually the feeling sets in that something is JUST WRONG), and yet I never considered its marketing this deep before. I didn't know it declined, and for some reason I just never figured someone was in a board meeting discussing edgy gum selling tactics for a young audience. And gamer gum? I will chew gum when I'm gaming, I get the focus potential, but still... gamer gum, wtf!? I mean, if any gum brand were to do it, 5 is the one with its dark backdrop and neon elemental infusion of colors, but still that's just so weird. The prior goofs also finally explains the stupid dare gimmicks on the packaging, I never quite got those. They almost made me feel weird for buying them, but once again, I don't stop to think "how do I identify with my gum" like some idiot marketing team is told to consider it. I just found Cobalt to be amazing. And once I learned not what marketing says, but what chemicals make gum good for your teeth vs those that are useless, I ditched Cobalt 5 for something better for me that was still pretty close to the flavor... because its just gum, its not about what phase of life I'm in. The topic to consider otherwise is as confusing, and surreal, as it is just curiously fascinating.
